PushFile will make a request to server.PushFile(filename, tempfolder string)

IE if you backup pictures, it goes in TEMP/pictures/File1, TEMP/pictures/File2, etc..

cards.desc:
<> required, () optional

# Does not require authentication #
generate <file> (password) --> generates new vault file, prints to screen and outputs to file

load <file/address> (password) Specifies vault file and loads into vault.dat

# Requires authentication #
update --> updates the vault.dat manifest
push <file/folder>
pull <file/folder>
lock --> locks vault by removing vault.dat

# Possible features #
ls --> prints current working directory
cd --> changes the current working directory

data.text: In regards to the malicious bytes being added to files. When you upload the files, save an image of the first block, first and second block, up to 1 + 2 +...+n (until the file is completed). And every time you download a file check it against the image you saved of it orignally being deconstructed. So compare: 1 (stored file) and 1 (archived file), 1 + 2 (stored file) and 1 + 2 (Archived file). If something doesn't match up you know that byte has been tampered with. The only problem with this is it has runtime O(n^2) so it's a pretty expensive operation.

data.text: Not necessarily. Running the command "hermes" could open a command line interface within itself (like what happens when you run "python"). It can be running the server sync and still allow the user to run client commands from within there. That way it can run in the background, and still be used as a client. Thoughts?

card.name: Add password encryption to vault file

data.text: The only problem is that the VaultID isnt so secret. Every computer on the network can acess all the vaultID's who have data stored on their computer. So you have the password to decrypt all their files
When we have a stable working release we will dub it v0.1 or whatever, and we will lock the branch and create a build. But we dont have to worry about that now
